context_evidences: - “But all female athletes in the state also are asked to report their history of menstrual periods: When they got their first period, how many weeks pass between periods and when they had their last one, to name a few. The information is reported on athletes’ annual physical form, which they are required to fill out with a physician and turn in to their school’s athletic director,” the piece from Katherine Kokal noted. Reference: https://floridapolitics.com/archives/562088-email-insights-desantis-country/ published on 2022-10-06 18:30:22

- Robert Sefcik, a member of the sports medicine advisory committee, said making the menstrual cycle questions mandatory rather than optional is consistent with national guidelines for sports physicals developed by the American Academy of Family Physicians, the American Academy of Pediatrics, the American College of Sports Medicine and other groups. Reference: https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-desantis-florida-sports-female-athletes-160560972802 published on 2023-02-04 00:04:46

- Ryan Harrison, the association’s spokesperson, confirmed the new recommendations were developed by its sports medicine advisory committee and approved in late January . It will now be considered by the association board of directors at its next meeting in Gainesville from Feb. 26-27. Reference: https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-desantis-florida-sports-female-athletes-160560972802 published on 2023-02-04 00:04:46

- These had exclusively been hard copy forms, but increasingly business is being routed to a new vendor called Aktivate, raising concerns. Reference: https://floridapolitics.com/archives/562088-email-insights-desantis-country/ published on 2022-10-06 18:30:22
correction_response:
This tweet is misleading. The recommendation to study menstrual cycles of student athletes is from the Florida High School Athletic Association, not directly from Ron DeSantis. The association is a private nonprofit organization, not a state agency under the governor's office. The proposed mandate hasn't had final approval and wasn't developed by DeSantis' office. The new recommendations were developed by the association's sports medicine advisory committee and are consistent with national guidelines for sports physicals. 
https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-desantis-florida-sports-female-athletes-160560972802
https://floridapolitics.com/archives/562088-email-insights-desantis-country/
note_1_text: The Florida High School Athletic Association proposed requiring menstrual cycle information on preparticipation athletic physical evaluation forms, which is consistent with national sports medicine guidelines. The organization is a nonprofit and not controlled by the Governor.    https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-desantis-florida-sports-female-athletes-160560972802
note_2_text: The above note fails to acknowledge that the Florida High School Athletic Association has members that are appointed by Ron DeSantis including Education Commissioner Manny Diaz and his appointees.    The statement "not controlled by the Governor" is questionable.    Same source: https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-desantis-florida-sports-female-athletes-160560972802

refute_evidences: - AP’S ASSESSMENT: False. The Florida High School Athletic Association is weighing the recommendation from an advisory committee, but no final decision has been made. DeSantis’ education commissioner is a member of the association’s board of directors and the commissioner also appoints three others, but the association is a private nonprofit organization, not a state agency under the purview of the governor’s office. Reference: https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-desantis-florida-sports-female-athletes-160560972802 published on 2023-02-04 00:04:46

- The Democratic response comes in the wake of a blockbuster story in The Florida Times-Union and other Gannett papers that introduced readers to what has become established practice in Florida schools.
